verses.text: Remember your Creator in the days of your youth, before the evil days come and the years approach when you will say, 'I have no pleasure in them.'
verses.comment: The call to remember God early in life anticipates approaching old age and its difficulties. This verse encourages devotion from youth, aligning with the tradition of sanctifying one’s entire life to God. The phrase 'Creator' in Hebrew is plural, possibly pointing to the majesty of God and serves as a subtle hint of the unity and mystery within God’s being (cf. Gen. 1:26).

verses.text: Before the sun and the light and the moon and the stars grow dark, and the clouds return after the rain;
verses.comment: Imagery of celestial bodies fading describes the coming of old age when the senses and faculties diminish. The recurring clouds suggest ongoing troubles near the end of life. The poetic language foreshadows eschatological themes—anticipating physical mortality and hinting at the soul’s longing for an eternal light.

verses.text: On the day when the keepers of the house tremble, and strong men stoop, when the grinders cease because they are few, and those looking through the windows are dimmed;
verses.comment: This allegorical description of the body portrays the frailty of age: keepers (hands/arms), strong men (legs), grinders (teeth), windows (eyes). The passage invites reflection on the dignity and sacredness of the body, which is destined both for resurrection and glorification (see 1 Cor. 15:42-44).

verses.text: And the doors on the street are shut, when the sound of the grinding is low, and one rises at the sound of a bird, and all the daughters of song grow faint;
verses.comment: Further symbols for advanced age: doors (mouth or ears), diminished noise (weakness), and difficulty sleeping. The 'daughters of song' fading is commonly interpreted as the loss of one's voice or hearing, connecting to the theme of remembering God while youthful strength remains.

verses.text: They are also afraid of heights and terrors on the way; the almond tree blossoms, the locust drags itself along, and desire fails—because man goes to his eternal home, and mourners go about the streets.
verses.comment: Almond trees blossom white, symbolizing graying hair. The locust and fading desire hint at advanced weakness. 'Eternal home' recalls humanity’s destiny after death and supports the belief in personal judgment and the continuity of the soul (cf. Matt. 25:46).

verses.text: Before the silver cord is snapped, or the golden bowl is broken, or the pitcher is shattered at the spring, or the wheel is broken at the well,
verses.comment: Metaphors for the fragility of life: valuable objects suddenly broken. This vivid imagery teaches about the preciousness and brevity of earthly existence, serving as a call to vigilance and spiritual preparation while there is still time.

verses.text: And the dust returns to the earth as it was, and the spirit returns to God who gave it.
verses.comment: Human mortality: body to dust, spirit returning to God. This anticipates the hope of bodily resurrection and eternal life (see 1 Cor. 15:53-54). The separation of body and spirit invites reflection on the immortality of the soul and responsibility before God.

verses.text: Vanity of vanities, says the Preacher; all is vanity.
verses.comment: This refrain resumes the theme of the book: apart from God, all human striving is emptiness. The Preacher’s relentless honesty sets the stage for the conclusion calling for reverence and obedience to God. The repetition emphasizes the futility of life without eternal purpose.

verses.text: And moreover, because the Preacher was wise, he still taught the people knowledge; he considered, sought out, and arranged many proverbs with great care.
verses.comment: The narrator commends the Preacher’s diligent search for wisdom and his careful instruction. The reference to proverbs connects to the wisdom tradition and shows the unity between reflective teaching and practical life guidance for the faithful.

verses.text: The Preacher sought to find pleasing words, and he wrote words of truth honestly.
verses.comment: True wisdom seeks both beauty and truth. This dual focus is reflected in the inspired Scriptures, which guide with authority and grace. This verse affirms the divine origin and lasting reliability of wisdom that is consistent with God’s revelation.

verses.text: The words of the wise are like goads, and like stakes firmly set are the collected sayings; they are given by one Shepherd.
verses.comment: 'One Shepherd' anticipates Christ—the true Shepherd who unites the faithful (see Ezek. 34:23 and John 10). Wisdom is both challenging (goads) and secure (fixed nails). The Shepherd motif subtly foreshadows unity under the guidance of Christ’s appointed leaders and the safeguarding of tradition.

verses.text: Beyond these, my son, be warned: of making many books there is no end, and much study wearies the body.
verses.comment: The preacher cautions against endless speculation, emphasizing trust in revealed wisdom over mere human inquiry. This principle upholds the sufficiency and protection of divine Truth accessible to the faithful—encouraging trust in sound instruction over endless private interpretation.

verses.text: The end of the matter, all has been heard. Fear God and keep his commandments, for this is the whole duty of man.
verses.comment: The path to true wisdom and fulfillment is revering God and obeying His commands. This summation can only be lived out fully by grace and in the context of a community ordered toward God. The language of 'duty' points to man's spiritual vocation and responsibility toward God.

verses.text: For God will bring every deed into judgment, with every secret thing, whether good or evil.
verses.comment: Final judgment is universal, comprehensive, and includes even secret actions. This belief in judgment according to works is affirmed throughout Scripture and points forward to the full revelation of God's justice and mercy in Christ. Spiritual preparation, repentance, and reception of grace are essential for a favorable judgment—always through God’s initiative.
